00020 /* 
00021  * cpu_time() returns CPU time in seconds.
00022  *
00023  * It will be safer to do dummy call right after program starts.
00024  * Since cpu_time() is double, it returns with a decimal point.
00025  * It returns 0.0 when error occurs, but is not ordinal.
00026  * It works on gcc/egcs (Sun,Linux,FreeBSD), Turbo C/LSI-C (MS-DOS).
00027  * You can get the latest version at address follows.
00028  * http://www.nn.iij4u.or.jp/~tutimura/c/
00029  * 2002/ 3/11 (C) tutimura@nn.iij4u.or.jp :-) Feel free to use.
00030  */
00031 
00032 /* How to use (not partial compile)
00033  *
00034  *  #include "cpu_time.c"
00035  *  ...
00036  *  main() {
00037  *      cpu_time(); <== dummy call
00038  *      ...
00039  *      printf( "time:%.2f(sec)\n", cpu_time() );
00040  *  }
00041  */
00042 
00043 /* How to use (partial compile)
00044  *
00045  * In common headder
00046  *  double cpu_time( void );
00047  */
00048 
00049 
00050 #ifdef TEST
00051 #include <stdio.h>
00052 #define TEST_MESSAGE(s) printf("by %s\n",s)
00053 #else
00054 #define TEST_MESSAGE(s)
00055 #endif /* TEST */
00056 
00057 #ifdef __STDC__
00058 double cpu_time( void );
00059 #endif /* __STDC__ */
00060 
00061 
00062 #if ( (defined(MSDOS) || defined(__MSDOS__) || defined(LSI_C)) && \
00063       !(defined(unix) || defined(__unix)) )
00064 
00065         /* MS-DOS */
00066 #include <time.h>
00067 #if !defined(CLOCKS_PER_SEC) && defined(CLK_TCK)
00068 #define CLOCKS_PER_SEC CLK_TCK
00069 #endif
00070 double cpu_time( void ) {
00071     clock_t t;  static clock_t last = (clock_t)-1;
00072     TEST_MESSAGE("clock()");
00073     t = clock();
00074     if (last == (clock_t)-1) last = t;
00075     return (double)(t-last)/CLOCKS_PER_SEC;
00076 }
00077         /* MS-DOS */
00078 
00079 #else /* unix */
00080 
00081 #include <sys/time.h>
00082 #include <sys/resource.h>
00083 #include <unistd.h>
00084 #ifdef RUSAGE_SELF
00085 
00086         /* Sun 5.5, Linux, FreeBSD, DJGPP */
00087 double cpu_time() {
00088     struct rusage tmp;
00089     TEST_MESSAGE("getrusage()");
00090     if ( getrusage( RUSAGE_SELF, &tmp ) ) return 0.0;
00091     return (double)(tmp.ru_utime.tv_sec)
00092           +(double)(tmp.ru_utime.tv_usec)/1000000;
00093 }
00094         /* Sun 5.5, Linux, FreeBSD, DJGPP */
00095 #else
00096         /* Sun 5.3 */
00097 #include <sys/types.h>
00098 #include <sys/times.h>
00099 double cpu_time() {
00100     struct tms tmp;
00101     TEST_MESSAGE("times()");
00102     if ( times( &tmp ) == -1 ) return 0.0;
00103     return (double)(tmp.tms_utime)/CLK_TCK;
00104 }
00105         /* Sun 5.3 */
00106 #endif
00107 
00108 #endif /* unix */
00109 
00110 
00111 #ifdef TEST
00112 int main() {
00113     int i, j, k;
00114 
00115     cpu_time(); /* dummy */
00116     for ( i=0; i<25; i++ ) {
00117         for ( j=0; j<30000; j++ ) {
00118             k=j*j*j*j;
00119         }
00120         j=k;
00121         printf( "time:%.4f(sec)\n", cpu_time() );
00122     }
00123     return 0;
00124 }
00125 #endif /* TEST */
00126 
00127 
00128 /*
00129  * This program calculates, like
00130  *     (double) clock()/CLOCKS_PER_SEC
00131  * does in ANSI, but in better way.
00132  */
00133 
00134 /* This works on ...
00135  *
00136  * SUN
00137  * gcc 2.5.8 (SunOS 4.1.3) -- warning getrusage()
00138  * gcc 2.6.3 (SunOS 5.5/5.5.1) -- warning getrusage()
00139  * egcs 1.1.2 (SunOS 5.5/5.5.1)
00140  *
00141  * Linux
00142  * gcc 2.7.2.3 (Linux 2.0/2.2, glibc2.0.7)
00143  * egcs 1.0.3 (Linux 2.0/2.2, glibc2.0.7)
00144  *
00145  * FreeBSD
00146  * gcc 2.7.2.1 (FreeBSD 3.2-RELEASE)
00147  *
00148  * MS-DOS
00149  * DJGPP
00150  * Turbo C 2nd Ver.1.0
00151  * Turbo C++ Ver.2.0
00152  * Turbo C++ Ver.4.0J
00153  * LSI-C86 Ver.3.3c
00154  */
